channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: APEC Trade Ministers Agree Statement Without Mentioning Tariffs
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies including the US and China agreed to focus on reforming global trade rules, after reaching an unexpected agreement by ignoring one of their biggest points of difference: tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Taicang Port Area International Container Terminal in Suzhou, China.

item.title: Treasuries, US-Made Japanese Cars Seen as Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Irish Exports to US Quadrupled in March on Tariff Threat
item.description: The value of exports from Ireland to the US quadrupled in March from a year earlier, on medical and pharmaceutical goods, the statistics office said.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: Sample bottles at the production lab in the Eli Lilly & Co. manufacturing plant in Kinsale, Ireland.

item.title: Trump Says US Will Set Tariff Rates for Other Nations in Weeks
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would set tariff rates for US trading partners “over the next two to three weeks,” saying his administration lacks the capacity to negotiate deals with all of its trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, alongside Scott Bessent, left, and Howard Lutnick at the White House in February.

item.title: Russian Inflation Likely Steadied as Rate-Cut Expectations Build
item.description: Price growth in Russia likely halted its acceleration in April for the first time in six months, bolstering the case for kicking off long-awaited monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

item.title: Singapore Firms Up Exports During Pause in Trump’s Steep Tariffs
item.description: Companies in Singapore are expediting exports to take advantage of a 90-day pause in hefty tariffs proposed by the Trump administration, a top official in the city-state said.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: The Brani Terminal beyond the Keppel Harbour in Singapore, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. Singapore’s port, already one of the busiest in the world, is facing a sustained period of congestion as vessel diversions to avoid the Red Sea push more container ships to the Asian maritime hub.

item.title: EU Exports to US Shot Up Just Before Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’
item.description: The European Union’s exports to the US rocketed in the month before President Donald Trump unveiled his so-called “Liberation Day” trade war with the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: Atlanta Fed’s Raphael Bostic on Monetary Policy During Extreme Uncertainty
item.description: How to keep the Fed's goals in balance with so much in flux.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Raphael Bostic, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market.

item.title: Odd Lots: Bostic on Fed Policy in Uncertain Times (Podcast)
item.description: This is obviously an extraordinarily difficult time to make economic forecasts. Nobody really knows how tariffs will effect the US economy. And beyond that, nobody knows what the ultimate state of tariffs will be, or if they’ll ever settle into a predictable rate. So how do you conduct monetary policy in this environment? On this episode, recorded at the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta, we spoke with Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic. He walked us through how he’s thinking about the dual mand
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Says He Sees One Rate Cut This Year, No Recession
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he expects the US economy to slow this year but not fall into recession, and reiterated that he sees one interest-rate cut in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Raphael Bostic, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, gestures as he speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Friday, Nov. 3, 2023. Bostic said policymakers have time to watch how the economy is evolving and be patient when it comes to interest-rate moves.

item.title: What’s the De Minimis Tariff Loophole That Trump Closed?
item.description: A Latin term that used to be little-known outside the world of customs brokers has become the stuff of headlines this year. That’s thanks to a decision by US President Donald Trump to close a tariff loophole for “de minimis” merchandise from mainland China and Hong Kong from May 2.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Samson Ellis

media:content.media:description: Packages at a neighborhood sorting center in Beijing, China.

item.title: Czech Rate Setters Backed ‘Moderately Restrictive’ Stance in May
item.description: Czech central bankers agreed monetary policy needed to remain “moderately restrictive” to address persistent domestic price pressures and uncertain global economic outlook, minutes from the May 7 meeting showed.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca

media:content.media:description: The city skyline seen from the roof of the Czech central bank headquarters in Prague, Czechia, on Tuesday, June 18, 2024. When Michl became governor the country was in the throes of its worst cost of living crisis in three decades and he pledged to bring inflation under control within two years, becoming one of the first central bankers in Europe to deliver on the goal.

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Doesn’t Reckon the World Is in a Currency War
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau dismissed a suggestion that a conflict in foreign-exchange policies is currently taking place.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Now ‘Relatively Close’ to Terminal Rate, Kazaks Tells CNBC
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Martins Kazaks said cuts in euro-zone borrowing costs are nearing their end-point if the base case for inflation returning to 2% this year materializes.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks, governor of the Latvian central bank, at the Financing a Better Future conference in Riga, Latvia, on Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2024. The economic revival in the euro area is likely to gain momentum, though dangers remain, according to European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ’s Most Dovish Member Warns Against Rushing to Raising Rates
item.description: The Bank of Japan’s most dovish board member warned against hurrying to raise the benchmark interest rate as authorities will need to closely monitor the impact of US tariffs on economic activity.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Toyoaki Nakamura

item.title: France’s Unemployment Rate Increased to 7.4% in Early 2025
item.description: France’s unemployment rate edged up at the start of the year, adding to signs of sluggishness in the euro area’s second largest economy even before threats of US trade tariffs further clouded the outlook
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: World Economic Forum Courts Lagarde as Its Next Leader After Founder’s Abrupt Exit
item.description: Klaus Schwab’s abrupt departure from the World Economic Forum, the influential organization he founded and led for more than half a century, has complicated carefully laid plans to persuade Christine Lagarde to assume the helm in a seamless transition, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Hugo Miller, Jan-Henrik Foerster, Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Malaysia Central Bank Ready to Act as Growth Outlook Dims
item.description: Malaysia’s central bank said it has the policy room to act as it expects economic growth to fall below the official forecast this year, with US tariffs dimming the outlook for the trade-reliant nation.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry, Kok Leong Chan

media:content.media:description: Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour

item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Tariff Truce Spurs Pacific Trade Rush, Boosting Global Shippers
item.description: Importers rushing to ship Chinese goods to the US using a short reprieve from paralyzing tariffs could provide a much-needed boost to global freighters.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Chloe Meley

item.title: India Examining US Request to Abolish Curbs on Ethanol Imports
item.description: India is reviewing a US request to lift restrictions on ethanol imports as it negotiates a wider trade deal with Washington to avoid punitive tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija, Rakesh Sharma, Shruti Srivastava

item.title: Romania to Hold Rates With All Eyes on Leu Path
item.description: Romania’s central bank will probably keep interest rates unchanged on Friday, with investors looking for any clues about the outlook for the leu after political turmoil pushed the currency to record lows.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Romania's central bank in Bucharest.

item.title: Trump to Keep 30% China Tariffs Till Late 2025, Analysts Say
item.description: Donald Trump’s tariffs on China will likely remain at a level expected to severely curtail Chinese exports to the US after the 90-day truce, analysts and investors say, suggesting Beijing may have to endure further economic pain despite active talks.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li, Yujing Liu, Iris Ouyang

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump before signing an executive order in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Trump is attempting to slash drug prices for Americans by more closely aligning their costs to lower prices paid abroad, renewing and expanding upon a failed push from his first term.

item.title: Japan’s Economy Shrinks for First Time in a Year Before Tariff Jolt
item.description: Japan’s economy was shrinking even before the bulk of US President Donald Trump’s tariff measures took force, leaving the economy at risk of sliding into recession as Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba heads into an election and the central bank weighs policy.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Ex-RBA Board Member Urges Rate Pause on High Fiscal Spending
item.description: Australia’s “very large” fiscal stimulus at a time when monetary policy is around neutral — neither stimulating nor slowing economic activity — suggests the Reserve Bank should keep interest rates unchanged next week, former board member Warwick McKibbin said.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan Aims for Currency Talks With US Based on Past Dialogue
item.description: Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato said he’ll seek another opportunity to talk with his US counterpart Scott Bessent next week to discuss currency matters, building on their dialogue last month.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Japanese 10,000 yen, left, and US 100 dollar banknotes arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, May 10, 2024. The Bank of Japan offered to purchase a smaller amount of government bonds in a regular operation on May 13 than it did on April 24 as it seeks to reduce its presence in the country’s debt market. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Traders Dial Back Rate Cut Bets in Asia on Easing Trade Tensions
item.description: Markets are pricing in less aggressive policy easing by central banks in emerging Asia’s export-dependent economies, following signs of reduced trade frictions between the US and China.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Is the Age of American Exceptionalism Nearing an End?
item.description: Markets delivered a withering verdict on Donald Trump’s trade war last month. They also may have turbocharged the decline of US economic primacy.
item.dc:creator: David Rovella

item.title: Trade War Brings Ontario Budget Deficit to Near Pandemic Levels
item.description: Ontario’s budget shortfall is expected to reach its highest level since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic as the effects of the trade war hurt economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Hughes

media:content.media:description: Doug Ford, Ontario's premier, arrives at the First Minister's Meeting at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, March 21, 2025. Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, is set to call a national election within days, seeking his own mandate from voters at a time when the country's businesses have been shaken by a trade war with the US.

item.title: Banxico Delivers Third Half-Point Cut as Growth Slows
item.description: Mexico’s central bank cut borrowing costs by half a percentage point Thursday after the economy narrowly avoided falling into recession and inflation remained within the target range.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Mexico's central bank headquarters, the Banco de Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world's largest economy.
